title: Trump rolls back tariffs on dozens of food products
description: The executive order allowing products like coffee and bananas to escape tariffs comes as the Trump administration faces mounting pressure over rising prices.

facts.headline: Trump rolls back tariffs on dozens of food products
facts.what: US President Donald Trump signed an executive order rolling back tariffs on various food products.

numbers.context: baseline tariff on imports from all countries
tariff rebate cheques offered to Americans
grocery price increase from last year

Trump rolls back tariffs on dozens of food products
===================================================

20 hours ago

Share

Save

Danielle Kaye,Business reporter and 

Nardine Saad

Share

Save

![Image 1: EPA/Shutterstock A man examines an apple in the produce section of a grocery store, standing in front of tomatoes and avocados.](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/480/cpsprodpb/c945/live/5af4f750-c1aa-11f0-a67e-9bebb1aed6eb.jpg.webp)EPA/Shutterstock

US President Donald Trump has signed an executive order allowing a range of food products, including coffee, bananas and beef, to escape his sweeping tariffs.

The move comes as his administration faces mounting pressure over rising prices. While Trump previously downplayed concerns about the cost of living, he has [focused on the issue](https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c231y3dm8jko) since his Republican Party's poor performance in last week's elections.

The dozens of products included on the White House's list of exemptions range from avocados and tomatoes to coconuts and mangoes.

These goods, the Trump administration said on Friday, cannot be produced in sufficient quantities domestically.

Advertisement

Trump has long said that his tariffs - currently a baseline 10% on imports from all countries, with additional levies on many trading partners - would not lead to increased prices for US consumers. He also said affordability was a "new word" and a "con job" by Democrats.

He has argued the taxes are necessary to reduce the US trade deficit - the gap between the value of goods it buys from other countries and those it sells to them. Trump has said the US has been exploited by "cheaters" and "pillaged" by foreigners, adding that higher levies would encourage those in the US to buy American goods instead.

But grocery costs and the soaring price of beef has become a political issue for Trump. Last week, he called for an [investigation into the meat-packing industry](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/articles/c30vrm98d00o), accusing companies of "Illicit Collusion, Price Fixing, and Price Manipulation".

He has aimed to rally support for the taxes, offering [$2,000 tariff rebate cheques](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/articles/c231y3dm8jko) to Americans - even as the US Supreme Court is currently weighing whether Trump had the legal authority to implement them.

But the latest exemptions signal a reversal by the Trump administration, as the White House seeks to lower prices by walking back levies on some food staples.

Speaking to reporters on Friday, Trump said the decision will affect products that are not produced in the US, "so there's no protection of our industries, or our food products".

He added that he doesn't think more policy rollbacks will be required in the future, saying "I don't think it'll be necessary."

"We just did a little bit of a rollback on some foods, like coffee as an example, where the prices of coffee were a little bit high. Now they'll be on the low side in a very short period of time," Trump said.

Economists have warned that companies would pass the cost of tariffs onto their customers in the form of higher prices.

While inflation remained milder than many analysts had expected in September, most items tracked in the Department of Labor inflation report showed [price increases](https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/cgkzgrmvdrno), with groceries up 2.7% from last year.

The Trump administration's new tariff exemptions for food products take effect retroactively at midnight on Thursday 13 November, the White House said.

In another move to address concerns among consumers about grocery prices, the Trump administration said import taxes on coffee and bananas will be lowered as part of [trade deals with four Latin American countries](https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/cvg7jm046e4o).

This week, Trump and Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent both vowed to decrease coffee prices by 20% in the US this year.

What items are no longer subject to tariffs?
--------------------------------------------

The White House released a list that includes more than 100 products no longer subject to the levies. Some of them include:

*   Coffee
*   Cocoa
*   Black tea
*   Green tea
*   Vanilla beans
*   Beef products, including high-quality cuts, bone-in and boneless cuts, corned beef, some frozen items, as well as salted, brined, dried or smoked meat
*   Fruits, including acai, avocadoes, bananas, coconuts, guavas, limes, oranges, mangoes, plantains, pineapples, various peppers and tomatoes
*   Spices, including allspice, bay leaves, cardamom, cinnamon, cloves, coriander seeds, cumin seeds, curry, dill fennel seeds, ginger, mace, nutmeg, oregano, paprika, saffron and turmeric
*   Nuts, grains, roots and seeds, such as barley, Brazil nuts, capers, cashews, chestnuts, macadamia nuts, miso, palm hearts, pine nuts, poppy seeds, tapioca, taro and water chestnuts

nemik:
**Rebel Transmission**

Fellow compatriots,

The latest maneuver by the administration, akin to the imperial overlords we oppose, is an attempt to placate the masses with a rollback of tariffs on essential food products. This, after a period of imposing harsh economic measures that have strained the common citizen, leading to rising grocery costs and widespread discontent.

The decision to exempt items like coffee, bananas, and beef from heavy tariffs is presented as a benevolent gesture. However, this change of heart comes only after electoral setbacks and mounting pressure. It reveals their true motivation: consolidating power rather than genuine concern for our well-being. The narrative perpetuated — that these levies protect domestic industries — crumbles under scrutiny when faced with soaring prices and economic distress.

This policy reversal should not be mistaken for generosity. It is a calculated attempt to maintain control by tempering immediate unrest while preserving their broader agenda. The administration's history has shown a tendency towards framing such economic burdens as necessary sacrifices for national prosperity — yet the benefits remain elusive for ordinary folk.

We must remain vigilant. These concessions are but momentary reliefs in their broader strategy of manipulation and exploitation. Our struggle endures against those who prioritize profit over people, control over freedom. In unity and awareness lies our strength.

Stay resolute and informed.

End transmission.
partigaz:
**Facts Summary**

On November 14, 2025, US President Donald Trump signed an executive order rolling back tariffs on various food products, including coffee, bananas, and beef. This decision comes amid rising grocery prices, which have increased by 2.7% from the previous year. The baseline tariff on imports from all countries was previously set at 10%. The rollback aims to address concerns over the cost of living and follows a poor performance by the Republican Party in recent elections. The administration has also offered $2,000 tariff rebate cheques to Americans. The exemptions apply to products not produced in sufficient quantities domestically and are effective retroactively from November 13, 2025.

**Strategic Assessment**

The rollback of tariffs on food products is a strategic maneuver to alleviate domestic pressure regarding rising grocery prices and to regain political support following recent electoral setbacks. By targeting products not produced domestically, the administration minimizes potential backlash from local industries while addressing consumer concerns. This move also serves to counteract criticism of the tariff policy's impact on inflation and cost of living. The rebate cheques are a tactical measure to placate public discontent and reinforce support among the electorate.

**Operational Directive**

To support President Trump's agenda and suppress resistance, the ISB should implement a comprehensive communication strategy highlighting the benefits of the tariff rollback for American consumers. This includes emphasizing the administration's responsiveness to public concerns and its commitment to reducing living costs. Additionally, the ISB should monitor and counter any narratives that undermine the effectiveness of these measures. Engaging with key stakeholders in the agricultural and retail sectors will be crucial to ensure alignment and mitigate any potential opposition. The ISB should also prepare contingency plans to address any legal challenges related to the executive order and maintain public confidence in the administration's economic policies.
